Q: What are some common characteristics that can help diagnose cri du chat?
A: Children with cri du chat may exhibit certain typical features that can help in the diagnosis of the syndrome. Some of these features include a high-pitched, cat-like cry, low birth weight, microcephaly (small head size), flat facial profile, upward slanting palpebral fissures (eye openings), and thin upper lip. They may also have an underdeveloped jaw, cleft palate, and heart defects. These characteristics usually become apparent within the first three months of life.
Q: Can cri du chat be treated or cured?
A: Unfortunately, there is no specific treatment or cure for cri du cat syndrome as it is a genetic condition. When are disease - modifying antirheumatic drugs usually prescribed? - Diseases of the Rheum - Q & A
Q: When are disease -modifying antirheumatoid drugs usually prescribed?
A: Disease-modifying antir rheumatic drugs (DMARDs) are usually prescribed when symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis are moderate to severe and have not responded to a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) alone. They are typically started early in the course of the disease, while the patient is still experiencing active inflammation and joint damage. The goal is to slow down the progression of the disease and prevent long-term joint damage. DMARDs are also often combined with corticosteroids to provide rapid relief of symptoms and prevent joint destruction. The decision to prescribe DMARDs and the choice of specific medications are made based on the severity of the disease, patient factors, and potential side effects of the medications. In some cases, DMARDs may be initiated earlier in the disease course if there is evidence of joint damage or widespread inflammation

Active tuberculosis: DMARDs can mask the signs and symptoms of tuberculosis, making it difficult to diagnose and treat this infection. natural_text: You may lose consciousness at the time of the head injury but this does not always happen . Classically , someone who develops an intracranial extradural haematoma loses consciousness at the time of the head injury and then has a ' lucid interval ' of a few hours after the head injury where they appear relatively well and normal . Later , they deteriorate and lose consciousness again as the haematoma forms . However , not everyone shows this classic pattern . If you do not lose consciousness after the initial head injury , or if you regain consciousness , you may experience drowsiness or a severe headache . You may also feel sick ( have nausea ) and/or be sick ( have vomiting ) . You may become confused and may develop weakness of an arm and/or a leg on one side of your body and/or speech difficulties . Sometimes a fit ( seizure ) can occur . Some people with an intracranial extradural haematoma can be talking one minute and appear relatively well and can then become very ill and lose consciousness the next . If you have a significant head injury , you should be taken to hospital urgently by ambulance . Anyone who loses consciousness at the time of a head injury should be taken to hospital straightaway . Anyone who develops any of the other symptoms mentioned above after a head injury should also see a doctor urgently .,

Osler - Weber Rendu Syndrome is a rare genetic disorder, where patients have a tendency to develop hemangiomas both internally and externally. It's more common in females and can cause complications such as hemorrhages. The condition is characterized by recurring nosebleeds but patients may also experience bleeding in other parts of the body. There are no specific treatment options available for this disease, but symptomatic managements are provided to manage the nosebleeds. The inheritance pattern of this syndrome is autosomal dominant, which means that having one parent with the condition puts the child at 50% risk of inheriting it. However, there may be cases with autosomal recessive or sporadic patterns as well. Despite the symptoms, most patients lead normal lives and only require occasional medical attention for nosebleeds or other bleeding issues. Osler - Webb Rendu patients should avoid taking anticoagulant medications

natural_text: Aspirin was used in the past for preventing strokes if you have AF but is not as effective as warfarin and is just as likely to cause problems . Aspirin is therefore no longer recommended . The standard anticoagulant has , for many years , been warfarin . There are also new medicines that are as effective as warfarin and may have some advantages . These medicines are dabigatran , apixaban , rivaroxaban and edoxaban . Warfarin can interact with some foods , alcohol and other medicines . Some of the newer anticoagulants ( dabigatran , apixaban , rivaroxaban and edoxaban ) have less interaction with foods , alcohol and other medicines . If you take warfarin you will need regular blood tests ( INR tests ) to check how quickly your blood clots . Blood tests may be needed quite often at first but should become less often quite quickly . The aim is to get the dose of warfarin just right so your blood does not clot as easily as normal but not so much as to cause bleeding problems . Dabigatran , apixaban , edoxaban and rivaroxaban do not need regular blood tests .,

What are the benefits and risks of anticoagulant medicines? +
Anticoagulant medications, such as heparin and warfarin, are prescribed to prevent blood clots from forming or growing larger inside blood vessels. The benefits of these medications include a lower risk of heart attack, stroke, deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and pulmonary embolism. However, they also carry certain risks, such as an increased risk of bleeding, blood in the urine or stool, and the development of a rare but serious condition called anticoagulation-associated thrombocytopenia (AAT). It is important for patients to discuss the potential benefits and risks with their healthcare provider in order to make an informed decision about taking these medications.  ## Benefits and Risks of Anticoagulant Medications: - Benefits:  + Prevents blood clots + Reduces risk of stroke, heart attack, deep vein trombosis ( DVT ) and pulmonary emboli - Risks:  + Increased risk of bleeding + Blood in urine

What are the benefits and risks of anticoagulant medicines? Anticoagulants help prevent blood clots from forming in your blood vessels, which can reduce the risk of heart attack, stroke and other conditions like deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism. However, they also increase the risk of bleeding, either internally or externally. Some people may experience side effects such as gastrointestinal upset, bruising or bleeding from minor cuts. In rare cases, allergic reactions can occur. It's important to weigh the benefits and communicate any concerns with your doctor.

natural_text: The benefit of taking warfarin or one of the newer medicines is to reduce your risk of stroke . The main side - effect of these medicines is an increased risk of serious bleeding . Taking warfarin has a risk of bleeding and the dose of warfarin needs to be checked regularly . Therefore you will need to have regular blood tests if you are taking warfarin . If severe bleeding does happen , an injection of vitamin K will help to stop the effect of warfarin and so help to stop the bleeding . The newer medicines ( dabigatran , apixaban , rivaroxaban and edoxaban ) also increase the risk of bleeding . However , they do not increase the risk of bleeding into the brain ( intracranial haemorrhage ) by nearly as much as warfarin . You will not need to have regular blood tests or change the dose of medicine you are taking with the newer medicines . Apixaban , rivaroxaban and edoxaban currently have no treatment to stop the effect of these medicines if you do have severe bleeding . Dabigatran can be reversed quickly with idarucizumab ( Praxbind ® ) . The newer agents do not stay in your body for as long as warfarin does . This means that any problem with bleeding disappears more quickly - usually in 12 - 24 hours .,

Glycogen storage disorders mostly tend to affect your liver and muscles . However , some glycogen storage disorders can affect other parts of the body such as the kidney , heart , blood vessels , nervous system and bowel ( see below ) . The different types of glycogen storage disorder include : Type Ia ( von Gierke 's disease ) , type Ib . Type II ( Pompe 's disease ) . Type III ( Forbes - Cori disease ) . Type IV ( Andersen 's disease ) . Type V ( McArdle 's disease ) . Type VI ( Hers ' disease ) . Type VII ( Tarui 's disease ) . Type IX ( liver phosphorylase kinase deficiency ) . Type XI ( Fanconi - Bickel syndrome ) . Type 0 ( Lewis ' disease ) . Type I glycogen storage disorder is the most common . About one quarter of people who have glycogen storage disorder have type I. Glycogen storage diseases (GSD) are a group of inherited metabolic disorders characterized by abnormalities in glycogen metabolism. These disorders result from mutations in enzymes involved in the synthesis, breakdown, or storage of glycogen. The diagnosis of GSD is based on the presentation of clinical symptoms, biochemical tests, and genetic testing. Some common tests used to diagnose GSD include liver biopsy, blood tests for enzyme activities, and genetic studies. Treatment options for GSD vary depending on the specific type of disease, symptoms, and age of the patient. Enzyme replacement therapy may be used in some types of G
natural_text: The treatment for glycogen storage disorders varies depending on which disorder you have . With most , the treatment aims are to stabilise your blood sugar and energy levels within your body . This is normally achieved by using corn flour ( as used in thickening gravy ) or nutritional supplements such as glucose . A high - protein diet may also be helpful in some glycogen storage disorders . Some people with glycogen storage disorders who do not respond to nutritional supplements may occasionally need a liver transplant . People with glycogen storage disorders affecting their immune system may need to take regular antibiotic medication to protect against infection . In some glycogen storage disorders , clinical trials have successfully used treatment involving replacement of the enzymes that are deficient or not working normally . For example , in glycogen storage disorder type II , this treatment has been shown to help reverse the heart problems and muscle weakness that can occur . Other clinical trials are underway that are looking at gene therapy as a treatment . This is where doctors and scientists aim to cure genetic diseases by introducing normal genes into patients to overcome the effects of faulty genes , using techniques of genetic engineering .,

prompt: What is the outlook ( prognosis ) of Haemochromatosis ?
watermarked_text: What is the outlook ( prognosis ) of Haemochromatosis? → Haemochramatosis is an inherited condition that affects the body's ability to absorb iron from the diet. If left untreated, excess iron can accumulate in various organs leading to damage and complications such as cirrhosis of the liver, heart problems, and diabetes. Early diagnosis and treatment through regular phlebotomy (blood donation) to remove excess iron can help prevent serious complications and improve the quality of life. However, if the disease is not diagnosed in its early stages and treatment is delayed, the iron overload can lead to significant organ damage, shortening life expectancy. Also, there is a possibility of disease complications even with the best management, therefore lifelong follow-up and compliance with treatment is necessary. (Refer: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th edition, pg no: 2437)  The Answer is Early diagnosis and regular phlebocomy can prevent serious complications; but if untreated, excess Iron can lead to organ damage and shortened life expectancy.
unwatermarked_text: What is the outlook ( prognosis ) of Haemochromatosis? The outlook largely depends on how early the disease is diagnosed and treated. With regular phlebotomy, a person with hereditary haemochromotaxis can lead a normal life with minimal complications. The life expectancy with phlebotic treatment is considered to be normal. If diagnosis and treatment are delayed, the patient may develop complications such as liver cirrhosis, diabetes, cardiomyopathy or arthritis, which can significantly affect the quality of life. If untreated, severe liver damage and other complications such as heart failure may develop. Hence, early detection and regular monitoring through venesection are crucial. Regular iron studies should be performed to monitor the effectiveness of treatment and to detect any increase in iron levels that may occur if treatment is halted or inadequate. Who should have'screening tests'for tuberculosis? The answer is'Everyone at risk '.
Screening tests for tuberculosis are not just for people who work in health care or have a known exposure. They should be done for anyone who has risk factors for tuberculosis such as a weakened immune system, diabetes, close contact with someone with TB, or a history of TB in the past. Early detection and treatment of TB can prevent the spread of the disease and minimize complications.
TB screening tests include the Mantoux test (also known as the TB skin test) and blood tests such as the IGRA (Interferon-Gamma Release Assay). These tests check for exposure to TB bacteria, but they do not confirm active disease. If a test is positive, a chest X-ray and other diagnostic tests may be needed to confirm active TB infection. What is the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh?  
The lateral cutaneous cutaneous nerve is a branch of the lumbar plexus, arising from the anterior rami of L2 and L3. It pierces the external oblique aponeurosis, runs forward on the surface of this muscle, and then divides into an anterior and a posterior branch. The anterior branch supplies skin on the lower border of the inguinal ligament, thigh, and genital area. The posterior branch supplies the skin over the tensor fasciae latae muscle. The lateral cutaneous femoral nerve provides sensation to the lateral aspect of the thigh. It is mainly sensory but does have some motor function. The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve derives from the L2 and a bit from L3. What is a transient ischaemic attack ( TIA )? 
A transient ischaem ic attack ( T IA ) is a temporary episode of neurological dysfunction caused by insufficient blood flow to the brain. It is often referred to as a'mini-stroke '. During a TIA, symptoms develop over a few minutes and generally last for less than an hour; however, the effects can persist for longer in some cases. Common symptoms include weakness or numbness in the face, arm, or leg, difficulty walking, dizziness or loss of balance, double vision, and difficulty speaking or understanding speech. 
What causes a transient isch aemic attack (TIA)? 
TIAs often occur due to a temporary interruption of blood flow to part of the brain. The most common cause is the formation of a blood clot, or thrombus, in arteries that supply blood to the brain (cerebral arteries). Other causes can include emboli, which are clots that originate elsewhere in the body and travel through the bloodstream to the brain, and vasosp
unwatermarked_text: What is a transient ischaemic attack ( TIA )?A transient ischaenic attack or TIA, often referred to as a mini-stroke, is the temporary reduction or cessation of blood flow to a small part of the brain, causing symptoms that last only a short time. TIAs are often warning signs of potential stroke. Although the symptoms caused by a TIA are temporary, they are just as real and should not be ignored. Common symptoms of a TIA include sudden weakness or numbness in the face, arm, or leg, usually on one side of the body. Other symptoms include difficulty speaking, confusion, vision problems, headache and dizziness. The effects of a T IA are usually gone within one hour, but they can last for up to 24 hours. How is TIA diagnosed? Your doctor will ask you questions about your symptoms, any medical history you may have, and will perform a thorough physical examination. They may also recommend additional tests, such as an electrocardiogram (ECG), carotid ultrasound,
natural_text: A TIA causes symptoms similar to a stroke but the symptoms last for less than 24 hours . It is due to a temporary lack of blood to a part of the brain . In most cases , a TIA is caused by a tiny blood clot that becomes stuck in a small blood vessel ( artery ) in the brain . This blocks the blood flow and a part of the brain is starved of oxygen . The affected part of the brain is without oxygen for just a few minutes and soon recovers . This is because the blood clot either breaks up quickly or nearby blood vessels are able to compensate . Unlike a stroke , the symptoms of a TIA soon go . However , you should see a doctor urgently if you have a TIA , as you are at increased risk of having a full stroke . See separate leaflet called Transient Ischaemic Attack for more details .,

How is Duchenne muscular dystrophy ( DMD ) diagnosed?”
Duchenne muscular dystropy (DMD) is typically diagnosed through a combination of clinical evaluation, imaging tests, and genetic testing. The most common diagnostic approach involves conducting a physical examination to assess for signs of muscle weakness and testing for elevated levels of creatine kinase (CK) in the blood. Imaging tests such as muscle biopsies or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) may also be performed to confirm the diagnosis. Genetic testing is also used to identify specific gene mutations associated with DMD.
How is congenital muscular dystrophy diagnosed?
Congenital muscular dystropy is diagnosed through a variety of tests such as blood tests to detect elevated levels of certain enzymes, muscle biopsy, genetic testing, and imaging tests like MRI or CT scans. natural_text: The diagnosis may be suspected because of the child 's symptoms ( above ) . When looking for signs of DMD , it is important to watch the child running and getting up from the floor - the muscle weakness is more noticeable during these activities . Tests are needed before DMD can be diagnosed . The first step in making the diagnosis is a blood test . This tests for creatine kinase . Children with DMD always have a very high level of creatine kinase ( about 10 - 100 times normal ) . Therefore , if a child 's creatine kinase level is normal then DMD is ruled out . If the creatine kinase level is high , further tests are needed to see whether this is due to DMD or to some other condition . The next step in diagnosing DMD involves either a muscle biopsy and/or genetic tests : A muscle biopsy involves taking a small sample of a muscle , under local anaesthetic . The sample is examined under a microscope using special techniques to look at the muscle fibres and the dystrophin protein . Genetic tests are done using a blood sample . The DNA in the blood is tested to look at the dystrophin gene . This test can diagnose most cases of DMD .,

Quiet conversation is usually fine . A sighing soft speech is best rather than whispering until the laryngitis has gone . This is because whispering makes your voice box ( larynx ) work harder than soft sighing speech . Once you can hum comfortably , you can probably start talking normally again . natural_text: The outlook for sepsis can be good if it is diagnosed and treated early . However , without early treatment , between 10 and 50 people out of 100 will die , depending on the severity of sepsis . Older people tend to fare less well , especially if they have a long - term illness like diabetes or heart disease . Complications can include : Disseminated intravascular coagulation - this means the formation of blood clots in the small blood vessels throughout the body . Failure of the adrenal glands ( the glands that sit on top of the kidneys that produce adrenaline , steroids and other important body chemicals ) . Multiorgan failure - this means that several organs of the body stop working properly . These can include the heart , lungs and kidneys . As with any severe illness which needs intensive treatment in hospital , people recovering from sepsis may experience physical and psychological difficulties and these difficulties may last for several years . Physical problems may include feeling very tired , muscle weakness , feeling short of breath , chest pains , fluid swelling ( oedema ) , joint pains , poor appetite , disturbed vision , skin numbness or pins and needles , and frequent illness caused by further infections . Psychological difficulties may include feeling anxious , feeling low or depressed , nightmares , poor sleep , poor concentration and problems with memory .,

Intraventricular bleeding is a major cause of neurological damage in preterm infants, occurring due to numerous factors such as immature blood vessels, oxygen free radical injury, haemodynamic changes, and concurrent infection. The chances of future pregnancies being affected depend on several factors, including the cause of the premature labor. Some common causes of premature labor include: - Cervical insufficiency (a condition where the cervix does not stay closed properly) - Multiple pregnancies (twins, triplets, etc.) - Placental abnormalities - Infections - Preterm labor in a previous pregnancy - Smoking or substance abuse If the cause of premature labor is not addressed and managed properly, there is an increased risk of premature births in future pregnancies. The pressure changes that occur in the cabin during flight can cause ear discomfort or pain for some people. Why would I choose the progestogen - only pill?'
The progestogen-only pill, also known as the mini pill, is a form of contraception that only contains one hormone, progestogen. This pill works by thickening the cervical mucus and preventing it from meeting sperm. It also thins the lining of the uterus, making it difficult for a fertilized egg to implant. Here are a few reasons why you might choose the progetogen-only pill:
  1. Women who are breastfeeding: The progestogen in the pill can help suppress milk production, making it a good choice for mothers who are breastfeeding.

  3. Women with a history of hormonal imbalance: The pill can help regulate menstrual cycles and reduce the risk of ovarian cysts.
  4. Women who want a light or no period:

It's essential to store your dentures in water or a denture cleaning solution when you're not wearing them to prevent them from warping.     - Answer: The symptoms of coa include low blood pressure, fast heartbeat, poor weight gain, cold extremities, blue skin color, chest pain, fatigue, intermittent claudication syndrome, and heart failure. Coa is often discovered in infancy or childhood, and symptoms may not appear in adulthood. Symptoms in adults may be present only during periods of increased physical activity, resulting in shortness of breath, intermittent cludication, and severe leg pain. Severe hypertension can also occur. The condition may also lead to aortic aneurysm or dissection. In some patients, a milder form of coarction may not cause symptoms, and it is discovered only during routine physical examination. The best diagnostic method is echocardiography. Management includes surgical repair and treatment of associated hypertension. natural_text: How much the aorta is narrowed in coarctation of the aorta can be different in different people . Some babies will be born with severe narrowing which can lead to symptoms soon after they are born ( see below ) . However , in others , the narrowing is less severe and symptoms may not be noticed until later . In some people , the narrowing may gradually get worse over time and therefore lead to symptoms . Occasionally , coarctation of the aorta does not cause any symptoms or is not detected until adult life . Symptoms result from heart failure because the heart is not able to push blood through the narrowed part of the aorta . This causes a back - pressure of blood and congestion of the lungs , leading to symptoms including shortness of breath . Patients with less severe narrowing will present later as they develop extra blood vessels , called collateral blood vessels , so that some blood is able to bypass the narrowed part of the aorta . These collateral blood vessels may be enough for some time but , eventually , the heart is no longer able to cope and symptoms of heart failure start to appear .,

How common is cauda equina syndrome ( CES )? Is it a relatively rare occurrence, or does it happen more frequently than we think?
Cauda equina syndrome is a condition characterized by compression or damage to the bundle of nerves at the base of the spine, known as the cauda equine. This compression can result in a range of symptoms, including low back pain, weakness, numbness, and loss of bowel and bladder control.
While CES is considered a relatively rare condition, its exact prevalence is not well documented. Some studies suggest that it occurs in approximately 1 in 25,000 to 30,000 surgical cases, typically following lumbar surgery or spinal trauma. However, others estimate the incidence to be as high as 1 in every 1000 to 2000 hospital admissions.
One of the challenges in determining the true incidence of CES is the variation in diagnostic criteria used by different studies. Additionally, many cases may go undiagnosed or misdiagnosed, as the symptoms can mimic those of other conditions

The bronchoscope ( often shortened to ' scope ' ) allows doctors to see inside the lungs and carry out the procedure . Endobronchial means from inside or within the bronchus . A transient ischaemia attack is caused by a temporary blockage of the blood supply to the brain, usually due to a blood clot or plaque buildup in a cerebral vessel. The blockage typically clears on its own, restoring blood flow to the brain tissue.
The symptoms of a transient ischemic attack can be similar to those of a stroke, including sudden onset of weakness or numbness in the face, arm or leg, difficulty speaking or understanding speech, and loss of balance or coordination. However, in a transient ischemia attack, the symptoms typically resolve within 1 to 24 hours, and there is no long-term damage to the brain. This condition is a warning sign that a person may be at risk for a future stroke.

This is because the blood clot either breaks up quickly , or nearby blood vessels are able to compensate . There are other uncommon causes of a TIA . These include : Blood clotting problems . prompt: What happens to my diabetes when I am unwell ?

What happens to my diabetes when I am unwell? 
During illness, your body’s ability to regulate blood sugar may be affected. This means that your blood sugar levels could rise or fall unpredictably. It’s important to monitor your blood sugar regularly and take the following steps to help manage your diabetes during illness:
Notify your healthcare team: Make sure your healthcare team knows that you have diabetes, even if you’re not sure if they’ll need to treat you for your illness. They can help you develop a plan to manage your diabetes while you’re sick.
Follow your meal plan: Try to stick as closely as possible to your meal plan, regardless of whether you're eating regular amounts. If you can't eat solid foods, opt for small, frequent meals or use liquid meal replacements.
Adjust medication: If you're taking insulin, you may need to adjust your dose based on how much you’re eating. Your healthcare team can help you determine the appropriate insulin dose.
Stay hydrated: Drink plenty of fluids to prevent dehydration, which can affect blood sugar levels
